content: The "Regulatory Accountability Act of 1996" requires Congress to approve regulatory costs under new and reauthorized federal laws. The "Regulatory Accountability Act of 1996" mandates that Congress approve regulatory costs under new and reauthorized federal laws. Section 421 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 has been amended to include a definition of a "controlled Federal private sector mandate" as a mandate that will result in costs of $100,000,000 or more for the private sector, or a provision in legislation authorizing appropriations to enforce such a mandate under existing federal law. The "Regulatory Accountability Act of 1996" requires Congressional approval for regulatory costs exceeding $100,000,000 imposed on the private sector under existing federal laws. Controlled private regulatory legislation refers to bills containing such mandates. Regulatory cost authorization specifies the allowed costs resulting from implementing or enforcing these mandates. The Regulatory Accountability Act of 1996 mandates Congressional approval for private sector regulatory costs exceeding $100,000,000. It defines controlled private sector mandates and specifies the costs allowed for implementing or enforcing these mandates. Amendments to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 further clarify the definition of costs related to rule implementation or compliance. RESTRICTION ON PRIVATE REGULATORY COSTS EXCEEDING CONGRESSIONAL AUTHORIZATION. Rules Exceeding Regulatory Cost Authorization Not Effective. The total costs for private sector compliance with covered regulations must not exceed the regulatory cost authorization. A proposed regulation cannot take effect without certification from the Director that it complies with the cost limit. Scoring of regulations by OMB requires submission of proposed regulations before issuance. The Director must certify that a proposed regulation will not exceed the regulatory cost authorization. Within 90 days of receiving a certification request, the Director estimates private sector compliance costs, checks for violations, and publishes the estimate and certification in the Federal Register. The Director must certify that a proposed regulation will not violate subsection (a)(1) or issue a finding that it would. The Director maintains and publicly discloses the costs of compliance for each covered regulation. An emergency exception exists if the President deems a regulation necessary due to an emergency. The term "covered law" refers to a provision of law that is a controlled Federal private sector mandate or a Federal private sector mandate that may be enforced using appropriated funds. The term "covered regulation" refers to a regulation issued under a covered law. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the agency. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The term "regulatory cost authorization" is defined in section 421 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Terms like "costs", "Federal private sector mandate", and "private sector" are also defined in the same section. The Act will be effective on January 4, 1997.
